review.title: Compositional Belief Update
review.abstract: In this paper we explore a class of belief update operators, in which the definition of the operator is compositional with respect to the sentence to be added. The goal is to provide an update operator that is intuitive, in that its definition is based on a recursive decomposition of the update sentences structure, and that may be reasonably implemented. In addressing update, we first provide a definition phrased in terms of the models of a knowledge base. While this operator satisfies a core group of the benchmark Katsuno-Mendelzon update postulates, not all of the postulates are satisfied. Other Katsuno-Mendelzon postulates can be obtained by suitably restricting the syntactic form of the sentence for update, as we show. In restricting the syntactic form of the sentence for update, we also obtain a hierarchy of update operators with Winsletts standard semantics as the most basic interesting approach captured. We subsequently give an algorithm which captures this approach; in the general case the algorithm is exponential, but with some not-unreasonable assumptions we obtain an algorithm that is linear in the size of the knowledge base. Hence the resulting approach has much better complexity characteristics than other operators in some situations. We also explore other compositional belief change operators: erasure is developed as a dual operator to update; we show that a forget operator is definable in terms of update; and we give a definition of the compositional revision operator. We obtain that compositional revision, under the most natural definition, yields the Satoh revision operator.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: A fundamental question is how such a change should be handled. There are various terms that effect a change in an evolving knowledge base, and these different rationality principles have been seen as a call for differences at the level of the background of postulates. For example, one may think that some changes have occurred in the world, with the result that we should update the representation of the world in an appropriate way. Or we may think that our earlier sources of information were fallible or incomplete, and that we now have better, more accurate information about the world.

sections.heading: 2. Background
sections.text: As described, our goal is to introduce a compositional method for making changes in faith. However, since it is also part of our overall goal to examine the location of a compositional faith change operation in all the different areas in which it can take place, we first outline some details for each of these different concepts that motivate changes in faith, along with some motivational considerations and some areas in which the different types of faith partially change. These operators have been introduced implicitly, through a series of postulates that each legitimate such operator has had to obey. However, in all of these areas there has been some controversy about the correctness of the different postulates, and we mention some of them during our proceeding, since our own approach to updates does not obey all standard postulates for updates. We begin with the historically earlier case of revision before moving on to our central concern of updating.

sections.heading: 3. The Approach
sections.text: This section discusses our approach. Following the intuition and motivation of the formal approach, we introduce compositional updates and subsequent erasures. We also consider the concept of compositional faith revision, but come to the conclusion that, at least in relation to our specific approach, there is no separate, unambiguous concept of compositional revision.

sections.heading: 3.1 Intuitions
sections.text: Our goal is to define the update operators in a compositional way, so that the actualization by formula µ defines the actualization of the syntactical components of µ. The general idea behind the actualization is that each model of the economy is replaced by the "nearest" model (s) in µ (Katsuno & Mendelzon, 1992). In our approach, the term "proximity" for each model of the economy (s) is partially determined by the syntactic structure of µ. That is, µ is recursively decomposed; the resulting (base case) literals are used to determine the models of the actualization by sets of words; and the results are combined depending on the connective (s) in micro. sections.heading: 5.2 Complexity
sections.text: That is, we are interested in how large the updated knowledge base could be. Unfortunately, if we apply it to any formula, the update algorithm may cause exponential spatial inflation, since the disjunctive normal form of a formula could be exponentially large. However, we are able to show that such exponential spatial inflation is inevitable for any algorithm of compositional updating. To achieve this goal, we need to introduce a so-called counseling engine (TM) and a non-uniform complexity class, see Johnson, 1990. A counseling TM is a counseling oracle that can be considered a function of a positive integer to the strings.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: The intention is to provide operators with transparent definitions based on the structure of the formula for the change of faith. As a result, we lose some of the standard postulates for updating, even though we satisfy a core group of the standard postulate. We achieve complete irrelevance of the syntax when the sentence for updating is replaced by the disjunction of its main implicits.The approach is interesting because, firstly, it is based on different intuitions than other operators, since it is based on a decomposition of the formula rather than on the models of the formula, and, secondly, it enables simple and (under reasonable assumptions) efficient implementation.

In general there has been less work dealing with systems that may be readily implementable (but see, e.g., Williams, 1996; Delgrande & Schaub, 2003). In this paper we develop a specific update operator where the operator is intended to be compositional, in that an update ψ ⋄μ can be expressed recursively in terms of the syntactic structure of μ. Thus, if a knowledge base is to be updated by a disjunction μ = a ∨ b, the idea is that this update will be a function of the update by a in a certain combination with the update by b. The update of the knowledge base by a conjunction μ = a ∧ b will also be a function (a different one) of the update by a in combination with the update by b. The goal is to arrive at an operator whose results are intuitive, in that its definition is based on a recursive decomposition of a formula; hence the (generally abstract) notion of update will be anchored in part in a more familiar computational setting. 2 Belief Revision and Contraction In the seminal approach of AGM (Alchourrón et al., 1985), postulates are proposed to constrain belief revision. In this approach, a knowledge base K is assumed to be a belief set, a set of sentences closed under logical consequence. The revision of a belief set by a formula, K ∗φ, is a new belief set in which the formula φ is believed. The interesting case is that in which ¬φ is initially believed, and so to attain a consistent belief set (assuming that φ is satisfiable), some beliefs have to be dropped. Exactly which beliefs must be dropped is not stipulated in the AGM approach; however, constraints in the form of postulates that govern what are seen as legitimate revision operators are given. In contrast, in their development of belief update Katsuno and Mendelzon (1992) represented the knowledge base by a formula in some language L.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper we explore a class of belief update operators, in which the definition of the operator is compositional with respect to the sentence to be added. The goal is to provide an update operator that is intuitive, in that its definition is based on a recursive decomposition of the update sentence’s structure, and that may be reasonably implemented. In addressing update, we first provide a definition phrased in terms of the models of a knowledge base. While this operator satisfies a core group of the benchmark Katsuno-Mendelzon update postulates, not all of the postulates are satisfied. Other Katsuno-Mendelzon postulates can be obtained by suitably restricting the syntactic form of the sentence for update, as we show. In restricting the syntactic form of the sentence for update, we also obtain a hierarchy of update operators with Winslett’s standard semantics as the most basic interesting approach captured. We subsequently give an algorithm which captures this approach; in the general case the algorithm is exponential, but with some not-unreasonable assumptions we obtain an algorithm that is linear in the size of the knowledge base. Hence the resulting approach has much better complexity characteristics than other operators in some situations. We also explore other compositional belief change operators: erasure is developed as a dual operator to update; we show that a forget operator is definable in terms of update; and we give a definition of the compositional revision operator. We obtain that compositional revision, under the most natural definition, yields the Satoh revision operator.
